Literature Review: In the realm of precision medicine, the integration of high-throughput data with time-to-event outcomes has become increasingly prevalent. Traditional survival analysis methods, such as the Cox proportional hazards model, struggle with high-dimensional data due to issues like overfitting and computational infeasibility. This literature review aims to provide an overview of advanced methods designed to address these challenges, focusing on feature selection, machine learning, and their applications in survival analysis. Recent advancements in feature selection have significantly improved the handling of high-dimensional data. For instance, the LASSO (Least Absolute Shrinkage and Selection Operator) method, introduced by Tibshirani (1997), has been widely adopted for its ability to perform variable selection and shrinkage simultaneously. This method is particularly useful in reducing the dimensionality of the data while maintaining predictive accuracy. However, the LASSO can only select a limited number of variables, which may not be sufficient in ultra-high dimensional settings. To address this limitation, Fan and Lv (2008) proposed the Sure Independence Screening (SIS) method, which efficiently reduces the dimensionality of the data before applying a more refined selection technique. SIS has been shown to be effective in identifying relevant features even when the number of predictors far exceeds the sample size. Machine learning techniques have also emerged as powerful tools for high-dimensional survival analysis. Random Forests, introduced by Breiman (2001), are ensemble methods that can handle high-dimensional data and capture complex interactions between variables. Ishwaran et al. (2008) extended Random Forests to survival analysis, developing the Random Survival Forest (RSF) method. RSF not only provides accurate predictions but also offers insights into variable importance, making it a valuable tool in understanding the underlying mechanisms of diseases. Another notable machine learning approach is the use of artificial neural networks (ANNs). ANNs have the capability to model non-linear relationships and can be adapted for survival analysis through the use of specialized loss functions. Faraggi and Simon (1995) were among the first to apply ANNs to survival data, demonstrating their potential in improving prediction accuracy. More recently, deep learning architectures, such as those proposed by Katzman et al. (2018), have further enhanced the performance of ANNs in survival analysis by leveraging the power of deep neural networks. In addition to these methods, Bayesian approaches have gained attention for their flexibility and ability to incorporate prior knowledge. For example, the Bayesian LASSO, introduced by Park and Casella (2008), combines the LASSO penalty with a Bayesian framework, allowing for more robust variable selection and uncertainty quantification. This method has been successfully applied to high-dimensional survival data, providing reliable estimates and credible intervals. Competing risks, where multiple types of events can occur, add another layer of complexity to survival analysis. Fine and Gray (1999) developed a subdistribution hazard model to account for competing risks, which has been widely used in clinical research. More recently, machine learning methods have been adapted to handle competing risks. For instance, Zhang and Zhang (2014) proposed a Random Forest-based approach for competing risks, which extends the capabilities of RSF to this more complex setting. The application of these methods to real-world datasets has demonstrated their practical utility. The Boston Lung Cancer Survival Cohort (BLCSC) study, one of the largest cancer epidemiology cohorts, provides a rich dataset for evaluating these methods. Using the BLCSC data, Chen et al. (2016) applied the LASSO and RSF methods to identify key genetic and environmental factors associated with lung cancer survival. Their findings highlight the importance of both genetic and lifestyle factors in predicting survival outcomes. In conclusion, the development of advanced methods for high-dimensional survival analysis has significantly advanced our ability to handle complex data in precision medicine. Feature selection techniques, machine learning algorithms, and Bayesian approaches offer robust solutions to the challenges posed by high-dimensional data. Future research should focus on integrating these methods with emerging technologies, such as electronic health records and genomics, to further enhance the predictive and explanatory power of survival models.
